A comparison of the "numbers shown under'V. for the 7 months does not tbei* fore give an accurate criterion of the vessels in Allied service at the different periods.Ij Including 13 vessels formerly shown under separate heading '* Tiading for Colonies." .*f "Bequisition" is here used to mean "requisition for full Government service." The vessels shown as "free from requisition" thereto? include the vessels that are requisitioned under the special liner requisitioning scheme, under which vessels, while running for Government accouC1 are run by their owners and accept some private cargo.Includes 18 vessels (47,006 G.T.) transferred from Norwegian flag under the Norwegian Agreement. As these require to be replaced Norwegian service bv British vessels they do not represent additional vessels available for British service. 1,600 GROSS TONNAGE AND OVER ON 1917.Lakes) as to render them not.available;for ocean-going trade or requisition.;. ! General requisitions have been served on the following lines, but the individual vessels only come gradually under the requisition as they arrive in the United Kingdom, or other specified place of discharge.\ These were formerly included in a separate main heading VI., on page 2. Includes two vessels carrying outward cargo to Gibraltar or Port Said, where homeward commitment is unknown.Aberdeen Line.Allan Line.Anchor Line.Asiatic S.N.
